Posts.Content: I'll add my congratulations here! This is a good group, you will find lots of great information and help here. Just ask. I found that sitting and sleeping in my over-size recliner (I'm not over-size, just the recliner... it's very comfy) was much easier than sitting in normal chairs and sleeping in bed. I used the big catheter bag almost exclusively the whole time, as it has much greater capacity. It is more awkward to walk with, but you get the hang of it. Get a small plastic trash can and let the bag sit in it when you are in the chair, bed, or whatever. That way if it should happen to leak the trash can will keep it contained. The bloating can be uncomfortable, but it will pass. Yeah, sorry, pun intended. It took me 3 days to pass the gas, but when I did I felt much better. Then a day later I had my first post op BM. That was a little scary, but it all came out in the end. Oh, ouch, I couldn't resist that one either. Last one, I promise.

Posts.Content: Due to the HIPA privacy regulations, no health care facility is allowed to give out test results to anyone who calls them on the phone. Technically. Some will do so if they know the caller personally. Some have a "code word" system in place so the caller can prove who he or she is. If the doctor (or nurse or lab tech) calls the patient, then he or she has a reasonable expectation that the person on the phone is actually the patient, and therefore is allowed to discuss test results. I know, it's crazy, but that's the world we live in now. The doc should have taken the time to explain this.

Posts.Content: There is always going to be some difference from one lab to another, that's why docs want to use the same lab all the time. Having been a Med Lab Tech myself, I can tell you that there will even be some difference (not large, but some) between two results run on the same machine using samples from the same blood tube. That's just the way things are.

Posts.Title: 5 years post RALP

Posts.Content: If you don't hear anything in a couple more weeks you can drop by or call your urologist and ask him what's going on. He should be able to bug the surgeon for the path results, or get them directly from the path lab. Unless the surgeon is your urologist? Either way, it is your right to have a copy of the results. If you don't get them in a reasonable amount of time make a pest of yourself at the doc's office until you get them. Now with that said, it was almost exactly one month from the day of my surgery until the day I got my pathology results. Sometimes it just take time. The wheels of progress grind slowly and all that.

Posts.Title: My pathology report

Posts.Content: The surgeon explained about the positive margin; he said that he has seen that type before and that it is rarely of any significance, but it is something to be aware of (he explained it in detail and even drew a sketch to make sure I understood). I did not see anywhere on the report a separate Gleason score for the positive margin, but I will double check. The surgeon said that I don't need to see him again unless I want to, that further follow-ups would be with my urologist... which is what the urologist had already told me. My next appointment with the uro is in 6 months, though I am welcome to come in any time if I feel the need. They did draw for a PSA yesterday, even though it's a bit early. They said that they would send me the results. He explained that if the PSA started creeping back up over time that I would probably want to do the radiation treatments. He was very thorough in making sure that I understood what that entailed and the reasoning behind it and how it works, though I already knew most of what he said from my earlier research. Replicant, I am not aware so far of any plans for a hyperspace bypass, but I have feelers out. If I hear anything I'll let you know. I seem to have misplaced my rabbit bones, but at least I know where my towel is.

I have called the surgeon's office a few times since, and they have always been very helpful.

Posts.Title: Good 6 month followup

Posts.Content: Yesterday I saw my urologist for my 6 month post op follow up. In a nutshell, he is pretty happy with where I am and how I am doing, as am I. He did start me on daily Cialis. I took the first one last night around 6, and by 9:30 had a couple of positive reactions. He said that I could possibly notice results the first night, but that it would probably take 4 days or so to build up in my body to optimal strength. I take last night as a positive hint of things to come. The doc did a DRE, which didn't surprise me since I had read about post surgical DREs here on the forum. It was fine, my PSA is still undetectable, so I'm good until October. Things are looking up. Now, I need to drop about 20 pounds. Ugh!

Posts.Content: Tomorrow will be my 3 year surgery anniversary (see my signature). I'll have a followup visit with the doc next week, so far my PSA has remained undetectable. I have minimal incontinence issues, just a little stress leak now and then (but they can happen at the darndest times). Levitra has worked well for me, though I have learned that timing is an important factor. Unassisted "morning wood" has been good for a year or more, and lately I have had a couple of nice unassisted evening surprises, so things there are looking up. Overall things are going well. Life is good.

Posts.Title: Spam in my pm box

Posts.Content: It is my understanding that the radiation treatments will cause most, if not all, of the prostate tissue to die eventually, over a period of 2 years or so. So at first I would think that fertility would not be greatly affected, but as more and more tissue dies off the prostate will function less and less, until eventually there will be no ejaculate and hence little to no sperm transport. Admittedly I am just guessing, hopefully someone who knows the facts will chime in.

Posts.Title: Seemingly random swelling 6 weeks post surgery

Posts.Content: A week ago last Friday night I suddenly experienced intense itching of the scrotum. Eventually I had to scratch it though I was careful. I had eaten my lunch in the park that day and figured I had probably sat in some chiggers (mites) or something. Soon after, it started swelling and eventually swelled up pretty big. I figured it was a reaction to the scratching and over the next couple days it returned to normal. Then later in the week I got an intense itch on the bottom of my right foot... followed by swelling. Over a couple of days it returned to normal. Then I realized that the week previously the same thing happened with my left foot. Today my right thumb started itching intensely followed by... yep, swelling. Now I can be pretty thick headed sometimes, but I'm starting to see a trend here. Does this sound familiar to anyone? Could this be related to my surgery? Wife thinks maybe it's something to do with my lymph system trying to find a new balance or something. If it happens again I'm going to call the doc, but I thought I would check with you folks to see if anyone else has experienced this. Maybe it's something totally unrelated. Thoughts?

Posts.Content: Hi all. I am almost 5 months post op now and doing fine, still in the zero club so far. I got very lucky with contenance, didn't have much trouble with that at all. I still usually use a thin light pad just in case for those little "oops" moments when I sneeze or something, but these days that rarely happens anymore. ED is still an issue, but recently I have had a few "stirrings" that are encouraging. My surgeon said that he was confidant that I would regain most of that function in time. My main question is about blood donation. I used to donate regularly, and I miss it. I have read in different places that the Red Cross will accept blood donations from us who have had the prostatectomy, provided the PSA remains undetectable for 12 months post op, though I haven't found anything about it on their site. Has anyone here confirmed or disproved this?

Posts.Content: Hello everyone. I had the DaVinci surgery 4 weeks ago today. Overall I think I am doing well. I have what are probably the normal aches, pains and twinges, and leak only a little every now and then. I wear a pad a day and a Depends overnight. Sometimes I think I am leaking more than I really am because the pad and briefs are so hot they make me sweat a lot. My urologist is satisfied with my progress so far, and I see my surgeon this Wednesday for his follow-up. Something that bothers me a good bit is urgency. I can urinate fine, and feel like I have emptied my bladder, but just a few minutes later feel like I need to go again. I can hold it ok, but sooner or later I have to run to the loo again. Sometimes I end up going 3 or 4 times an hour. This is very annoying, as it interrupts my work day. I find that it doesn't bother me so much if I stand up and walk around, but I have a desk job. I have one of those special cushions with the cut-out in front, and that helps some but not enough. I was wondering if this is pretty common or not. The worst thing about my surgery so far is that I had one heck of an allergic reaction to whatever scrub they used to clean the incision sites, as well as the adhesives on the tapes they used on me. It took a few days to develop, but once it got started it was like super-charged poison ivy. I have never had a rash like that before, and hope I never do again. It is only just now fading. You can bet I'll be asking the surgeon what chemicals they scrubbed me down with so I can put them on my allergies list. Did anyone else have that happen? I'll try to fill out my profile and signature as time allows. Thanks for the great forum. Art
Posts.Title: Hello from a newbie and a couple of questions.

Posts.Content: Thanks for the ideas fellows. Today I spent most of the morning kneeling in front of my desk on some makeshift knee pads, and that helped a lot. I was able to keep my loo trips down to once an hour or so. Then this afternoon I was dealing with an inspector and though I had to sit in an office chair I was so busy that I didn't notice "the urge" for the biggest part of the afternoon. This actually lasted until supper time when I got a little pepper up my nose and sneezed a few times. That blew my control, so to speak. Oh well. I see my surgeon tomorrow for his followup and discussion of my biopsy report. Wish me luck.
Posts.Title: Hello from a newbie and a couple of questions.

Posts.Content: Also, I thought someone might chime in about the rash. Some googling reveals that allergic reactions to surgical scrub solutions and adhesives are not uncommon. Art
